perturbation.original_text: The appointment of the Agent hereunder shall terminate upon the earlier to occur of (a) forty-five (45) days after the last day of the Subscription and Community Offering, unless the Company and the Agent agree in writing to extend such period and the OTS agrees to extend the period of time in which the Securities may be sold, or (b) the receipt and acceptance of subscriptions and purchase orders for all of the Securities, or (c) the completion of the Syndicated Community Offering.
perturbation.changed_text: The appointment of the Agent hereunder shall terminate upon the earlier to occur of (a) fifteen (15) days after the last day of the Subscription and Community Offering, unless the Company and the Agent agree in writing to extend such period, or (b) the receipt and acceptance of subscriptions and purchase orders for all of the Securities, or (c) the completion of the Syndicated Community Offering.
perturbation.explanation: This change reduces the period for the agent's appointment termination from 45 days to 15 days. This timeline is potentially problematic. Pennsylvania law provides a cooling-off period or specifies particular procedures or review periods for certain types of financial transactions, including securities offerings. Reducing this period to 15 days could put the contract in conflict with consumer protection regulations or securities regulations, if those regulations require a longer period or a specific procedure to terminate the offering.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential conflict with Pennsylvania consumer protection laws or securities regulations regarding cooling-off periods or review periods for financial transactions.

perturbation.original_text: (i) The Company will make generally available to its security holders as soon as practicable, but not later than 60 days after the close of the period covered thereby, an earnings statement covering a twelve month period beginning not later than the first day of the Company's fiscal quarter next following the effective date of the Registration Statement (as defined in Rule 158 of the Securities Act Regulations) that will satisfy the provisions of Section 11(a) of the Securities Act.
perturbation.changed_text: (i) The Company will make generally available to its security holders as soon as practicable, but not later than 180 days after the close of the period covered thereby, an earnings statement covering a twelve month period beginning not later than the first day of the Company's fiscal quarter next following the effective date of the Registration Statement (as defined in Rule 158 of the Securities Act Regulations) that will satisfy the provisions of Section 11(a) of the Securities Act.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the availability of the earnings statement to 180 days after the close of the period contradicts the requirement to provide it as soon as practicable, and places it far outside the normal reporting timelines expected under the Securities Act. The rule states the report should be provided no later than what is set forth in Section 11(a).
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Act of 1933, Section 11(a); potential violation of SEC Rule 158 requiring timely earnings statements.

perturbation.original_text: (r) Other than in connection with any employee benefit plan or arrangement described in the Prospectus, the Company will not, without the prior written consent of the Agent, sell or issue, contract to sell or otherwise dispose of, any shares of Common Stock other than the Securities for a period of 180 days following the Closing Time.
perturbation.changed_text: (r) Other than in connection with any employee benefit plan or arrangement described in the Prospectus, the Company will not, without the prior written consent of the Agent, sell or issue, contract to sell or otherwise dispose of, any shares of Common Stock other than the Securities for a period of 30 days following the Closing Time.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the restricted period for selling shares of Common Stock from 180 days to 30 days can present a conflict. In the U.S. and other jurisdictions, lock-up agreements for IPOs and similar offerings typically extend for 180 days (or longer) to prevent market saturation and maintain stock price stability. A 30-day lock-up may be inadequate, especially if there is significant insider or early investor ownership, and it could violate standard underwriting practices or regulatory guidelines if a longer period is expected by regulatory bodies to ensure fair market practices following an offering.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential conflict with standard underwriting practices and expectations of regulatory bodies regarding lock-up periods to maintain fair market practices after an offering.
